document.docTitle: Leptocera rhadinofulva Buck & Marshall 2009, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of New World Leptocera Olivier (Diptera, Sphaeroceridae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of New World Leptocera Olivier (Diptera, Sphaeroceridae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description . Very similar to
L. fulva
, with the following differences ( Figs. 260–263 ): Posterior section of surstylus yellow (medium to dark brown in
L. fulva
), with long medial bristle slightly more tapered apically; bristles of apical series with fine tips, mostly slender but increasing in robustness toward apical bristle which is stout. Male cercus distinctly longer than in
L. fulva
, clearly surpassing apex of posterior section of surstylus, base wider and with somewhat angulate inner margin (base of cercus not widened in
L. fulva
, with inner margin nearly straight).

Female terminalia ( Figs. 264–266 ) similar to
L. fulva
but sternite 7 less produced posteromedially (at most as in Fig. 266 , usually less).

Type material .
Holotype ♂ ( MUSM ) and 118 ♂♂ , 92 ♀♀ paratypes ( DEBU , MUSM ): PERU , Dpto. Madre de Dios , Los Amigos Biol. Stn.,
2–14.vi.2006
, Paiero & Klymko. Other paratypes : 1 ♂ , 1 ♀ , same but
3–13.vi.2006
, malaise ( DEBU ). Paraguay. Dpto. Guairá: 2 ♀♀ , Villarrica,
17–28.xii.1950
, Foerster ( IMLA ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 260–266 .
Leptocera rhadinofulva
sp.n. (Argentina). Male terminalia (phallus and postgonites omitted): (260) lateral; (261) posterior, right cercus omitted; (262) ventral, cerci omitted; (263) sternite 5. Female terminalia: (264) dorsal; (265) spermathecae; (266) ventral. ce—cercus.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 267–272 . Postgonites and aedeagal complex of
Leptocera fulva
group. Postgonites of (267)
L. dicrofulva
sp.n. (Ecuador), (268)
L. prolixofulva
sp.n. (Venezuela). Aedeagal complex of
L. fulva
(Belize): (269) posterior; (270) anterior; (271) lateral; (272) dorsal. bcp—basal connection between postgonites, bp—basiphallus, dp—distiphallus, ea—ejaculatory apodeme, pa—phallapodeme, pg—postgonites.

Etymology . The species name refers to the slender, tapered bristles of the apical series of the posterior portion of the surstylus (Gr. rhadinos : slender, tapering).
Distribution . Widespread in tropical South America from Venezuela and Ecuador (east of the Andes) to northern Argentina below 1,600 m .

Discussion . The differences with regard to
L. fulva
are mentioned in the description. See also Discussion under
L. prolixofulva
sp.n.
